mil3.6.2:1.2: “Venerable Nāgasena, is the Buddha all-knowing and all-seeing?”
mil3.6.2:1.3: “Yes, your majesty, the Buddha is all-knowing and all-seeing.”
mil3.6.2:1.4: “Then why, venerable Nāgasena, did he proclaim the training steps for his disciples gradually?”
mil3.6.2:1.5: “But, your majesty, is there some doctor who knows all the medicines on this earth?”
mil3.6.2:1.7: “And would that doctor, your majesty, administer medicine to a sick person at the time of being ill or when not ill?”
mil3.6.2:1.8: “He would administer medicine to a sick person, venerable sir, at the time of being ill and not when not ill?”
mil3.6.2:1.9: “In the same way, your majesty, the Blessed One who is all-knowing and all-seeing did not proclaim a training rule to his disciples at the wrong time, but when the time was right he proclaimed a training rule to his disciples, which is not to be transgressed all life long.”
